steps.theme: Achieving resilient food security difficult with population growth and climate variability

steps.title: overview
steps.content:
The Sahel region of Africa encompasses a vast expanse of the continent, spanning from the Atlantic Ocean to the Red Sea.

The Sahel is a semi-arid region and experiences limited rainfall throughout the year. Niger, a land-locked country in the western Sahel, is one of the poorest countries in the world and relies primarily on subsistence rain-fed agriculture, a livelihood experiencing increasing stress with a changing climate.

Niger and the Sahel are subject to recurrent and devastating droughts as well as an increase in the occurrence of floods. Food insecurity and low levels of social and manufactured capital inhibit the population’s resilience to increasingseasonal variation in rainfall, as well as longer-term climatic changes.

steps.title: livelihoods
steps.content: Which livelihoods and production systems are most threatened?

steps.aside:
Livelihoods

Population distribution

Niger

80% of Niger’s population is rural, and reliant on subsistence agriculture for 40% of their food consumption.

The desert areas of northern Niger are sparsely populated.

http://www.fews.net/west-africa/niger/food-security-brief/may-2014

Livelihoods

Livelihood strategies

Niger

Pearl millet and sorghum are the main crops grown crops vulnerable to climate shocks.

99% of all crops in Niger are rainfed. Only 1% of crops are produced with irrigation or flood retreat systems.

steps.title: Stressors and shocks
steps.content: What are the main stressors and shocks Nigerien livelihoods are exposed to?

steps.aside:
Stressors & shocks

Population growth

Niger

The fertility rate in Niger is 6.76 live births per woman, the highest in the world.

(https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/resources/the-world-factbook/geos/ng.html)

Niger’s current population of 18 million is growing at a rate of 3.25%, one of the highest in the world. The population could exceed 50 million by 2040.

(https://www.cia.gov/library/publicati ons/resources/the-world-factbook/geos/ng.html),

(www.wfp.org/countries/niger)

Stressors & shocks

Malnutrition

Niger

Chronic malnourishment is a serious problem in Niger: 42% of children are chronically malnourished and 1 in 8 children do not reach the age of 5.

In the southern regions of Niger, over 50% of children suffer from chronic malnutrition.

(www.wfp.org/countries/niger)

Stressors & shocks

2011 – drought conditions

Niger

Niger receives the majority of its rainfall between June and September.

Year-to-year fluctuations in rainfall create a tenuous situation for food security.

2011 was marked by drought conditions with some areas receiving well below the mean precipitation (- 158).

One year later, the situation almost reversed – with some areas receiving up to 204mm above the average.
